He asked me if I could not give him a Passport of my own, and make it out in the name of his Mother, which it was very customary in Spain for persons to assume— I told him that as a general rule, I gave my own Passports, only to Citizens of the United States; and I endorsed the Passports of foreigners from their own Ministers when they were going to America.— When they could not obtain passports from their own Ministers; if they had permissions from the Alien-Office to reside here; I would endorse them as good to go to America, and had done so in several cases. I considered every person as having a right to go from this Country to the United States, whom the Laws of this Country did not restrain, and if my Passport for that effect was required, I would give it in any form that would be accepted. I would leave it therefore at his own option, whether to take my endorsement upon his licence from the alien Office; or an original Passport from me. He said he would in the first instance try the endorsement; and if that should not succeed, he would ask me for an original Passport. And he had the same requests to make for several of his Officers who are with him— I promised him the same for his Officers, as for himself— There was also at the Office a Mrfrom the house of G. & J. Abel and Co. to speak upon the subject of their Letter to me— He said the Vessel which they had, waiting, made every day of delay expensive, and they wished for an answer as soon as possible. I told him I had already made enquiry to see Lord Castlereagh about it, and would lose no time, in endeavouring to see him— And that I would give Messrs: Abel notice of the answer as soon as I should receive it— Mr Oliver was likewise at the Office, and said there were accounts from New-York to the 23d. of March.— That the U.S. Senate had confirmed unanimously the nomination of Mr Pinkney as Minister to Russia, but refused connecting with it the special mission to Naples— Upon which Mr Pinkney had declined the Mission to Russia— He said he believed Mr Pinkney had relied upon having a present from the Merchants, who were interested in the claims upon the Government of Naples; if he should succeed in obtaining indemnity for their losses— I considered it as a very desperate case; but Mr Oliver thought that the fears of the present Neapolitan Government might be wrought upon, to grant compensation for the spoliations of Murat.— The three despatches from the Secretary of State, forwarded from Liverpool by Mr Maury were at the Office— They were of the 6. 7. 20. and 27. Feby:—and contained a Letter of Authority and Instruction to negotiate a Convention, concerning the fisheries— A Letter authorizing me to examine and settle the Accounts of the American Consuls in Great-Britain and Ireland for disbursements on account of destitute American Seamen—with a Letter of Credit upon the Brothers Baring and Co. for my drafts to pay their accounts— Duplicates of all these Papers, and of a Letter from Mr Monroe, enclosing one from Mr Williams a Senator from Tennessee to him, requesting that official copies of Governor Dobbs’s Commission and Instructions might be obtained— These papers were sent, six weeks ago— An enclosure from Mr Purviance, with a Despatch for Mr Russell at Stockholm, and a Letter from Mr William Vaughan.— As Mr Speyer is going to-morrow for Hamburg, I desired Mr Smith to give the Packet for Mr Russell to him.— The company, and the despatches occupied me until past five O’Clock, at the Office, and it was about seven when I got home.— The verdure is just now beginning to appear upon the hedges, and the leaves on the trees are beginning to disclose themselves— But the season is three weeks more backward than it was at this time last year.— I find by the Newspapers that there was a considerable fall of Snow, at Paris on the 14th of this Month, as there was here.

24. VII. By this morning’s Post, I received a Letter from Mr Grubb, with the information that the Night before last there was a fire in the house adjoining the American Consular Office, but that the Books and Papers of the Office were saved— He writes from the New-England Coffee-House, to which the Office is for the present removed— A Letter from the Brothers Baring and Co: enclosing one to them from Mr Simpson the Consul at Morocco, advising them that he had drawn a new bill upon them for £100. They ask my directions and authority to accept the Bill, and the return of his Letter.— A Note from the Chevalier de Freire, the Portuguese Minister, enclosing two Packets which he requests me to forward by a good opportunity to the United States— One of them is for a Mr Correa de Serra, the newly appointed Portuguese Minister in the United States, and the other for Mr: Rademaker, the Portuguese Chargé d’Affaires and Consul General— I answered three Letters lately received from Mr Maury. We had company to dinner—Mrs Elmsley, the Sister of Mr W. N. Boylston, and Admiral Hallowell—Mr and Mrs Dickason—Mr: William Vaughan, Miss Barbara Vaughan and Mr: Petty Vaughan. Mr: & Mrs Delafield, Mr and Mrs King, and her brother Mr Gracie, and Mr J. A. Smith— He brought me out a Letter, dated at Kilmarnock in Scotland; from a man named John Philips, who cannot spell, but who has invented a new system of Sailing, which he offers to the patronage of the American Government— Our Company left us between 11. and 12. O’Clock— Mr Smith stays.

25. VII.— Wrote to Messrs: Baring brothers and Co. returned to them Mr Simpson’s Letter, requesting them to pay the Bill of which he advises them in it— Sent them likewise the Letter from the Secretary of State, requesting them to pay my drafts upon them in favour of the Consuls for expenditures on account of distressed American Seamen— Answered also the Note yesterday received from the Chevalier de Freire. Mr J. A. Smith returned to London, in the Curricle— I walked to Kew-Bridge, and there took the Stage and went into London. Called at Lord Castlereagh’s house, but he was not at home— At the Office I received Letters from Mr Harris at St: Petersburg, and from Mr Simpson the Consul to Morocco.— Harris’s Letter gives information of the Death of Mrs Krehmer, and of Mrs S. Cramer. It encloses also a despatch for the Secretary of State, which I left with the Packets from the Chevalier de Freire to be sent by Mr Rawle— I had invited this Gentleman to dine with us next Tuesday; but he sent an excuse, intending to leave London for Liverpool on Monday, to embark for America— Mr Simpson’s Letter was to explain the cause of his Bills, upon the Brothers Baring, and to request me to authorize the payment of the two last— I walked from the Office to the third Milestone, where the Coachman with the Curricle overtook me— Then rode home. John and Charles had come home to dinner.— In the Evening they went with George to an itinerant Show—Gyngell—Slight of hand tricks, and a dwarf 28 inches high.

26. VI:15. Despatch to the Secretary of State, and wrote a page of this Journal without retrieving arrears— Note from Mr Murdoch inviting us to dine with him the 4th: of May— Rode out in the Curricle with Mrs Adams, over Hounslow Heath to the 13th: Mile Stone. By the Evening’s Post I received Letters from Mr Maury, and from a Dr Goodlet arrived at Liverpool from America— He brought me despatches from the Secretary of State, which Mr Maury has forwarded to me by the Mail-Coach.— Dr Goodlet encloses two Letters of Recommendation from Mr Monroe, and Mr Clay— He is going from Liverpool to Scotland upon business of his own, concerning which he asks my advice—and he expects to come to London in June— After dinner I took a half an hour’s walk with Mrs Adams and George whom we met returning from school. In the Evening the weather being clear, I shewed George the six signs or Constellations of the Zodiac Taurus, Gemini, Cancer, Leo, Virgo and Libra; with several other Constellations. We sat up to see Antares rise, at about eleven O’Clock— The Planet Jupiter is in Libra. We compared the visible Stars, with the Charts of Bode’s Uranographia.

27. VI:30. Answered the Letter from Mr Simpson the Consul to Morocco— Went into London with Mrs Adams and George, who dined at Mr. Delafield’s. Called at Lord Castlereagh’s but again failed of finding him at home.— At the Office I found the despatches brought by Dr Goodlet, and forwarded from Liverpool by Mr Maury— There was a Letter from the Secretary of State partly in cypher— A printed copy of a Message from the President to the House of Representatives of the United States, transmitting two Letters from the Spanish Minister Onis to the Secretary of State, and Mr Monroe’s answer all written in December and January last— There was Mr J. A. Smith’s Commission as Secretary of Legation to the Court of Great-Britain, and a packet of despatches for Mr Harris at St Petersburg— The card of invitation that I had received for the dinner at Somerset House mentioned that the doors would be opened at 2. O’Clock, and dinner on Table at 6. I went between 2. and 3 O’Clock; but finding upon enquiry that there was nobody there, returned to the Office; after calling at a Booksellers to speak for a missing leaf in a small Euripides that I had purchased there, and which he promised to supply on Monday Morning— At the Office I received also a Note from a Mr Cooke, the Under Secretary of State, informing me that the Exequatur of Mr Ingraham’s Consular Commission, was ready to be delivered— About five O’Clock, I went again to Somerset-House, and found the Company assembling. I went through the Apartments where the Paintings are exhibited— Many of them are very good, but the proportion of portraits is much greater than at any exhibition that I had ever seen here before. It was precisely twenty years since the last exhibition I had witnessed at this place— And now as then the finest Portraits are those painted by Beechey and Lawrence. The Historical Paintings now are fewer, and do not appear to me better executed. The Company at the Dinner amounted to upwards of two hundred persons; among whom were the Dukes of Kent, Cumberland, and Sussex—of Bedford and Somerset, almost all the Cabinet Ministers; many of the nobility the Lord Mayor, the Archbishop of York and several Bishops—the Russian, Spanish and Dutch Ambassadors; Swedish, Danish, Portuguese, Bavariand and Wurtemberg Ministers—the Diplomatic party were seated almost all together at a table, opposite to the President, Mr West— The dinner was tolerable— The toasts after dinner—the King as the Founder of the Academy—The Prince Regent, its Patron—The Queen and Royal Family— Then the Duke of Sussex and the Society of Arts, Manufactures and Commerce. the Marquis of Stafford, and the Royal Institution. The Royal Society. (Sir Joseph Banks, the President was not present, and not toasted) The Earl of Aberdeen and the Society of Antiquaries—The Lord Mayor and the City of London—And the foreign Ambassadors and Ministers present— The Duke of Sussex and the Earl of Aberdeen made short speeches in returning thanks for the toasts in which they were mentioned. The Marquis of Stafford simply rose and returned thanks— The Lord Mayor and the Ambassadors said nothing— The Duke of Kent after a speech of Eulogium upon Mr West the President, proposed his health, for which he returned thanks with a Speech. There was a band of music, which performed various airs and marches— And after dinner a sort of prayer was chanted to the words of Non Nobis Domine. God save the king was likewise sung— The company broke up, between eight and nine O’Clock— I asked Lord Castlereagh when he could see me, and he appointed Monday Morning at eleven O’Clock. I asked Count Lieven, whether he should soon send a Courier
to St: Petersburg. He said in the course of ten or twelve days; and he promised to send by him the Packet that I have for Mr Harris. I had ordered my Carriage at nine O’Clock, and waited for it, near half an hour. I then went to Mr Delafield’s where I found Mrs Adams and George— There had been company there to dinner, and they had all been to see Covent-Garden Theatre. We returned first to Craven-Street where I found two invitations, which I took home with me without reading; as it was late, and we did not alight from the Carriage. When we got home I found the invitations were, a Card from the Lord Steward, (Marquis of Cholmondeley) inviting the American Minister to dine with His Serene Highness the Prince of Saxe-Cobourg at St: James’s on Wednesday next at a quarter before seven O’Clock—Full dress—dated, Board of Green Cloth 25. April 1816. and An Answer on Sunday is most particularly requested— The other was—The Master of the Ceremonies, is commanded by His Royal Highness the Prince Regent to invite the American Minister and Mrs Adams to Carlton House on Thursday next the second of May at Eight or between eight and nine of the Evening, to be present at the Ceremony of the Marriage of Her Royal Highness The Princess Charlotte Augusta of Wales with His Serene Highness Leopold George Frederick, Duke of Saxe, Margrave of Meissen, Landgrave of Thuringuen, Prince of Cobourg of Saalfeld, dated this day; and with a note— The Company will be in full dress, but the Ladies without Hoops.— To this invitation no answer is necessary, and the direction upon the other to answer on a particular day, seems intended to balance the courtesy of inviting by an assumption of authority in demanding the answer— It was between one and two in the morning when we got home. 23 [symbols]

28. VIII. Sent Antoine into London, with the Answer to the Lord Steward’s invitation, to dine with the Prince of Coburg on Wednesday; and with an invitation to Mr and Mrs Delafield to dine with us on Tuesday— They were engaged.— Attended Church. Prayers for the second Sunday after Easter were read by Mr Carr—and the Sermon by Mr Millman, from Matthew VII:1. [“]Judge not, that ye be not judged.” a dull invective upon Slander. I wrote to Dr Goodlet—decyphered the Letter received yesterday from the Secretary of State; and wrote a few lines in my Journal; the arrears of which are troublesome; and constantly threatening to become irreparable. I received a Letter from R. Boyd at Paris, and a Note from Mr John David Towle containing an invitation from Nathaniel Brickwood Esqr Prime Warden of the Fishmonger’s Company, and the rest of the Wardens and Court of Assistants, to dine with them at Fishmonger’s Hall on Thursday the twenty-third of May next at half past 5. O’Clock, to meet their Royal Highnesses the Dukes of Kent, Sussex and Gloucester, and the rest of the honorary members and the Right Honourable the Lord Mayor— This is the company to which the Lord Mayor belongs. I wrote last Wednesday a Letter to Coll: Aspinwall, and circular to the Consuls Maury at Liverpool, Fox at Falmouth, Ingraham at Plymouth, and Luke at Belfast in Ireland, enclosing copies of the Letter of Instruction of 27. February, from the Secretary of State, relative to the Settlement of their accounts for disbursements to relieve destitute American Seamen.— Yesterday Mr Smith had prepared the copies, and the Letters, and I signed them, to be dispatched.

29. VI:30. Answered the Letter, received a few days since from Mr Harris at St: Petersburg.— Went into London with Mrs Adams, and called at eleven O’Clock at Lord Castlereagh’s house in St: James’s Square— The Chevalier de Freire the Portuguese Minister was there before me, and had a short interview with his Lordship— Baron Fagel the Dutch Ambassador came in while I was waiting in the antichamber. I was only a few minutes, and mentioned to him the Letter that I had received from Messrs: George and James Abel & Co. which I read to him; with the copies of the Answers they had received from the India house, and the Board of Controul. Lord Castlereagh asked me to send him copies of these papers, and said the matter should be arranged, as soon as possible— He also desired me, if I could conveniently, to call upon Mr Robinson the Vice-President of the Board of Trade, and to converse with him on the subject. I went to the Office in Craven-Street, and thence walked with Mrs: Adams to N. 60. Conduit Street; Mrs King’s lodgings, where I left her— Thence I went to the Board of Trade; and obtained an interview with Mr Robinson— He at first sent me word that he was engaged with a person by an appointment; and would be glad if I could call again to-morrow morning. But being informed that I would not detain him more than five minutes and that I had called upon him at the request of Lord Castlereagh, he received me— I read to him the Letter from the Abel’s and its enclosures, from which it appeared that a Clearance cannot be obtained for an American Vessel, from London to any of the British Ports in India— Mr Robinson at first said that the Convention of 3d: July last could not be understood to authorize that— I said that if such a Construction should be given to it as would exclude our vessels from that advantage, it would certainly be altogether different from what I and my Colleagues expected at the Negotiation and conclusion of the Convention— He said there was not in the terms of the Convention, any explicit allowance of an indirect trade from the United States to the British Possessions in India— It was not however his intention to deny that it was understood when the Convention was concluded, that American Vessels might go
indirectly, through other Countries to British Ports in India, but surely that could not mean to give them the privelege of clearing from the Ports of England itself, to go there— He remembered we had urged the indirect voyages through South-America, and that we ought to be placed on as favourable a footing as other Nations; none of which could clear out for British India from this Country. I admitted in reply that the indirect trade to India was not given in express words by the Convention— But a general trade was given, without restriction upon the outward voyage— The homeward trade was restricted to the direct voyage to the United States.— 25 [symbols] The restriction being expressed in the one case its omission in the other obviously implied that it was not to operate. I was confident there had been a judicial decision in this Country upon the corresponding Article in the Treaty of 1794. to that effect. But he perfectly well knew, and now candidly admitted that it was on all sides understood at the negotiation of the Convention that it contained the indirect trade to India for American vessels; it was even explicitly recognized in the Notes of the British Plenipotentiaries during the discussion— And I had observed in a printed account of the Debates in Parliament on the passage of the Bill which he had introduced, for carrying the Convention into effect, that a question had been put to him by some member upon this very point; to which he was stated to have answered that the Convention did allow an indirect American trade to India, but restricted the return voyage to the United States. He neither explicitly admitted nor denied that such a question had been put to him, and that he had given this answer— It seemed as if he had been since told that he had conceded too much by that acknowledgment— That the express words of the Convention did not give the indirect trade, and that an effort has been making, to narrow the Construction of the Article so as to exclude us at least from trading to India through England— I told him that if the Clearance from British Ports should continue to be denied, it would produce one of two effects— It would either in a very great degree defeat the indirect trade which the Convention was intended to contain; or it would merely operate to put American vessels to some additional trouble and expence, and some change of Custom-house forms— All the important commerce of the world centered so much in Great-Britain, that we could not have any indirect trade to India, of any importance, which would not bring our Vessels going thither to England on their way. If Clearances from England for India should be effectually prevented; the trade itself would be good for Nothing— But as it was admitted American Vessels might clear out from any other Country, for India, what other effect would the denial to clear them from British Ports have than to compel them to clear out for intermediate Ports, there to take fresh Clearances for their ultimate destination— Indeed I could not see how the Clearances from England could be denied while the indirect trade through other Countries was admitted to be granted. It was not given in express terms I admitted— It was given by obvious and just inference he admitted— But if the inference was just, as it respected a trade through other Countries, it was just for a trade through England. Granting that a question might be made whether the indirect trade was stipulated at-all, it would apply to all other Countries as well as to England— There was no special exception of England, nor was there any argument which would warrant the refusal of clearances from English, Ports, but that which would annihilate the indirect trade altogether— I had seen Lord Castlereagh and shewn him these papers this Morning, and had understood from him that this matter would be satisfactorily arranged; and it was at his Lordship’s request that I had called to have this Conversation with him on the subject— He said I might rely upon his disposition to give the fullest effect, and most faithful execution to the Convention. He would see and converse with Lord Castlereagh concerning it this day; as he should meet him in the house of Commons; and he would do every thing in his power for our accommodation— On returning to the Office, I had copies immediately made out of the Letter from G and J. Abel and Co: and the enclosed papers, and sent them with a Note to Lord Castlereagh. Mr Dorsey, who brought me a Letter last Summer from Mr Hellen, and Mr Tarbell, who has just returned with his wife from France called at the Office— I invited them both to dine with us to-morrow— But Mr Dorsey was engaged; and Mr Tarbell apologized. Mrs Tarbell being unwell, and not able to go out— I received a Letter from Mr Maury. At 4 O’Clock I left the Office to walk part of the way home— Opposite Carleton House, there was a great crowd of People collected in Pall Mall— It was to see the Prince of Cobourg who this day came in state, into London.— We had met the royal Carriages going out to Sir Joseph Banks’s seat at Hounslow Heath, to take him up— He came this Morning from Windsor, 26 [symbols] and after visiting the Prince Regent at Carlton House he took his residence until the marriage, at the Duke of Clarence’s apartments in St. James’s Palace— There had also just been presented an address from the City of London to the Prince Regent, of Congratulation upon the Peace— I had met the procession of the Sheriffs Carriages, on their return, in Charing Cross.— At the corner of the new Street opening from Pall-Mall opposite to Carlton-House, I met the Earl of Carysfort, and stood with him nearly half an hour in Conversation. I had seen his name in the Newspapers as having been present at the dinner on Saturday at Somerset-House, but did not see him there— He told me that he had been to look at the Pictures, but did not stay to the dinner; being quite an invalid, with his asthma— He said Lady Carysfort was also unwell, confined to her chamber— That they had been only a few days in town and should not stay long; as he had let his house in Berkeley Square— We had some loose political conversation, in which he said he was now of the opposition; but he was disposed to be very candid towards the Ministers. He disapproved their large military establishment, but he knew they must gradually reduce it, and the reduction must require considerable time, to be effected with convenience— I said I thought it must end by a partition of France; and he expressed a wish that it might— He said there would be a falling off of the Revenue here, particularly in the proceeds of the assessed taxes, which I very much doubt— After leaving Lord Carysfort, I walked to the fifth milestone, near which I was overtaken by the Carriage with Mrs Adams— We were at home about seven, and I received a Letter from Mr Maury. In the Conversation
this morning with Lord Castlereagh, I began by shewing him the Letter of Instructions from the Secretary of State to me, of 27. Feby. directing me to consider it as an authority and instruction to negotiate a Convention respecting the fisheries. After perusing it he asked me, if a new Power had been sent to me. I told him there had not. But I was authorized to shew him that Letter, which my Government had undoubtedly considered as containing a Power sufficient for the purpose. He said that conformably to the agreement at our interview on the 9th. instant he had already sent out authority and instructions to Mr Bagot for this Negotiation, which it would be more convenient to have conducted at Washington, because he was authorized also to give instructions to the British Commanders on the Coast, according to the result of the discussions. I replied that it would be personally more agreeable to me, and I presumed more convenient to my own Government to have the arrangement made at Washington. As however this authority had been transmitted to me, it was my duty to lay it before him, and to act upon it, if this Government should be so disposed— He said he thought it would only make the subject more complicated, without bringing it nearer to any result, and I readily acquiesced in this opinion. He said nothing of the nature of the proposition which Mr Bagot is authorized to make.

30. VII. Wrote to the Secretary of State—despatch 43—reporting the substance of my Conversation with Lord Castlereagh yesterday, upon the negotiation concerning the fisheries: and answering the despatches brought by Mr Goodlet— Wrote a few lines in my Journal— Walk to Hanwell and Ealing— We had company to dinner—Mr and Mrs: King—Coll Talmadge, Messrs: John and Henry White, Mr Bibby, Mr Moses and Mr J. A. Smith. He brought me out a Note from Mr del Real; requesting me to appoint a time, when I can see him; and one from Mr Sanders, mentioning that he is to have a party at his lodgings to-morrow Evening, and requesting that my Son George may go to it— Our Company left us about 11. O’Clock. The Night was clear, and Antares had just risen to be visible.

Day.— A great and unwelcome change is taking place in the course of my occupations— The increased frequency of my calls to London; as well upon business public or private, as for attendance at Court, or by invitations to dining parties, Evening Assemblies, the Theatres &c. which began in February, now consumes so much of my time that I can neither keep my Journal nor my correspondence at their level— Arrears of both are forming in spite of me, and threaten to become irretrievable— I am often out late at Night, and then rise late in the Morning. Whenever I go to London, the Day from Breakfast time is gone; and the more I have of materials for the Journal, the less of time there is for writing it. I have ceased hearing George read in French altogether, and read nothing myself in the morning but the Newspapers— I rise with the utmost irregularity, between six and nine.— Write as much as I can until ten or eleven, when we Breakfast. When I do not go to London, I write or read Letters and papers on business from breakfast time until five O’Clock— Walk an hour or more. dine between six and seven; and after dinner, read Letters or papers, again, and pass the Evening until ten or eleven in conversation— The Postman usually comes with Letters while we are at dinner, and I receive an average of three or four Letters every day— When I go to London and return to dinner I get home about seven. When I dine or pass the Evening in London it is one or two in the Morning before I reach home. I find the difficulty and slowness of writing daily growing upon me; and expect to be very shortly forced to give up journalizing almost entirely.
